Lock result codes (LKR_x)
[Resource Locking and Serialisation]

Resource locking result codes. More...

Defines

#define LKR_OK   0 /**< Operation successful */
 Operation successful.

#define LKR_STALE   -1 /**< Lock's owner is dead, lock is removed */
 Lock's owner is dead, lock is removed.

#define LKR_OWN   -2 /**< Lock belongs to the caller */
 Lock belongs to the caller.

#define LKR_TIMEOUT   -3 /**< Timeout waiting for lock to be removed */
 Timeout waiting for lock to be removed.

#define LKR_ERROR   -4 /**< Some other error occurred */
 Some other error occurred.

#define LKR_SYNTAX   -5 /**< Lockd failed to parse the request */
 Lockd failed to parse the request.

Detailed Description

Resource locking result codes.

These result codes allow the caller to know if a lock request succeeded, and, if not, why. They are a necessary part of resource locking.

  • LKR_OK. All is well, the lock request was successful.

  • LKR_STALE. The requested resource is locked, but the lock is stale. That is, the process that owned the lock has died. Your process may lock the resource.

  • LKR_OWN. The lock exists, and belongs to you.

  • LKR_TIMEOUT. There was a timeout while waiting for the lock to be removed. This result code is not returned by the daemon. Handling timeouts is the responsibility of the BBS library and they are reported locally.

  • LKR_ERROR. A strange error has occur-ed. Whoops.

  • LKR_SYNTAX. The lock daemon could not understand your request.

Any other result code greater than zero denotes the PID of a process holding the lock in question.
